Award.AwardTitle: Beyond the Standard Model: Searching for New Physics in Cosmology and Colliders
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Neal Weiner at New York University.

The Standard Model is known to be an incomplete theory of nature. Most of the matter of the universe (the "dark matter", solidly established by astronomical and cosmological observations) consists of something undiscovered, and thus there must exist new particles not in the Standard Model. Additionally, the presence of the Higgs boson and the expected properties of a quantum field theory together suggest that new particles and fields will be discovered at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). However, because the properties of both of these new sets of particles are unknown, a broad theoretical study is required in order to evaluate what possible new particles might be discoverable with present techniques and what new search strategies might be needed. As part of this project, Professor Weiner intends to investigate a broad range of theoretical scenarios, both top-down (motivated by new and existing theoretical scenarios) and bottom-up (motivated by new signatures) as well as their experimental implications for the LHC and for direct-detection experiments. Additionally, Professor Weiner will pursue studies to understand the sensitivities of dark-matter searches, with a focus on the sensitivities of the astrophysical assumptions present in the existing analyses.

The broader impacts of this project will be wide ranging. Professor Weiner will involve both students and postdocs in his research program, providing opportunities to train future scientists. He will also continue his participation in physics summer schools (as invited), such as the TASI, CLASHEP, ICTP and Les Houches programs, to educate current PhD students on active research topics. Finally, he will continue his efforts to engage the public through public lectures as well as his outreach at the high-school level, anchored by his continued participation with the Governor's School summer program in North Carolina.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have come to understand over the last decades that the majority of the universe is dark. In particular, the galaxies we observe are held together by a myterious dark matter, which is six times more prevalent by mass than ordinary atomic matter. This mysterious substance has never been observed in a lab. In order to discover and understand it, we must consider broad classes of scenarios of what it may be, and from those design experiments.


The most popular scenario, that of a WIMP or weakly interacting particle, has been well explored. In such a model, the dark matter is a distant cousin of ordinary matter, interacting with us through weak nuclear forces. The absence of any sign of such a particle has prompted us to consider alternative models. In particuar, we have studied a class of ``hidden sector'' models, where the dark matter exists with properties akin to ordinary particles, but only very weakly talking to us.


In these scenarios, dark matter can be much lighter than WIMPs, and thus the energy it has as it flies around the universe is much lower. When it collides with ordinary matter, it deposits much less energy and thus new ways to look for it must be found. One such fashion is if dark matter has excited states, not unlike atoms. If so, dark matter might collide with itself in galaxies, exciting these states which would then decay down and produce observable signals. For dark matter lighter than WIMPs, this energy scale is often in the x-ray range, and an x-ray line is possibly detectable as originating from galaxies and clusters of galaxies.
In many models of dark matter, the Higgs boson provides a natural window to the dark matter. The Higgs boson provides mass for all the known fundamental particles, and thus may be connected to the dark matter as well. To this end, we must understand the properties of the Higgs boson. In particular, if the Higgs boson comes with other Higgs-like particles, they can influence the signals we observe at the LHC.
We showed that in many models of this sort, the signals show up in searches for a rare process where the Higgs boson is produced with two top quarks. The presence of the new Higgs boson changes the top quarks so they decay very rarely into the new Higgs bosons, which looks very much like top quarks with Higgs bosons. We showed such signals were detectable and that the LHC can constrain broad regions of the parameter space available for these models. As a consequence, the prospect for new discoveries at the LHC is even greater.
